intro: Siphocampylus westinianus var. chamissonianus, commonly known as the Chamisson's siphocampylus, is a rare and specialized plant species native to the Pacific Northwest of the United States. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes familiar plants such as carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its finely divided, fern-like leaves. The plant typically grows in moist, shaded environments, such as along stream banks or in forest understories. Its flowers are small and clustered in umbels, a common feature among members of its family. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered a vulnerable species in its native range.
